page.title: 13FIELD STUDIES AT MITCHELDEAN
page.content: The Wilderness Field Study Centre stands near the edge of a hilltop, 850 feet above sea level at the north eastern edge of the Forest of Dean. There is a magnificent view eastwards over the hill ridges around Mitcheldean and May Hill, and beyond to the Malvern Hills, Severn Plain, and distant Cotswolds. There is great variety in the local rocks, and the whole area around Mitcheldean is a classic one for demonstrating the relationship between geology and vegetation, flora, land use, and human activities both past and present. The house, which was built in 1824 became a Field Study Centre in l968. There is a Director of Studies, with an assistant, and up to 52 resident students can be accommodated, together with up to 6 staff. There are also facilities for day visits.
